Problem:
Consider a system where the temperature distribution in a rod over time is modeled by the heat equation \\(u_t = k u_{xx}\\), where \\(u_t\\) is the time derivative of temperature, \\(u_{xx}\\) is the second spatial derivative, and \\(k\\) is the thermal diffusivity constant. We explore the effect of applying a Fourier transform \\(\\mathcal{F}\\) to the initial temperature distribution, particularly how this transform impacts the system dynamics.

Given the temperature profile \\(u(x, T)\\) at time T, can we precisely determine what interventions (application of \\(\\mathcal{F}\\) or \\(\\mathcal{F}^{-1}\\)) were used only by knowing the temperature at \\(u(x, T)\\)?
Explanation: The final temperature profile \\(u(x, T)\\) might result from various combinations of applying and/or reversing the Fourier transform, along with the natural evolution under the heat equation. The multiple possibilities and similarity in outcomes from different sequences of transforms make it impossible to uniquely identify which interventions were executed.
